nodes.name: Augustus
nodes.succession: Great-nephew and adopted son of Julius Caesar; became de facto emperor as a result of the 'first settlement' between himself and the Roman Senate.

nodes.name: Tiberius
nodes.succession: Natural son of Livia Drusilla, Augustus' third wife, by a previous marriage; stepbrother and third husband of Julia the Elder, daughter of Augustus; adopted by Augustus as his son and heir.

nodes.name: Caligula
nodes.succession: Great-nephew and adoptive grandson of Tiberius; natural son of Germanicus; great-grandson of Augustus.

nodes.name: Claudius
nodes.succession: Uncle of Caligula; brother of Germanicus; nephew of Tiberius; great-nephew and step-grandson of Augustus; proclaimed emperor by the Praetorian Guard.

nodes.name: Nero
nodes.succession: Great-nephew, stepson, son-in-law and adopted son of Claudius; nephew of Caligula; great-great-nephew of Tiberius; grandson of Germanicus; great-great-grandson of Augustus

nodes.name: Galba
nodes.succession: Seized power after Nero's suicide, with support of the Spanish legions

nodes.name: Otho
nodes.succession: Appointed by Praetorian Guard

nodes.name: Vitellius
nodes.succession: Seized power with support of German Legions (in opposition to Galba/Otho)

nodes.name: Vespasian
nodes.succession: Seized power with the support of the eastern Legions (in opposition to Marcillinus)

nodes.name: Titus
nodes.succession: Son of Vespasian

nodes.name: Domitian
nodes.succession: Son of Vespasian

nodes.name: Nerva
nodes.succession: Appointed by the Senate. First of the “Five Good Emperors”.

nodes.name: Trajan
nodes.succession: Adopted son and heir of Nerva. His reign marked the geographical peak of the empire

nodes.name: Hadrian
nodes.succession: Adopted son and heir of Trajan

nodes.name: Antoninus Pius
nodes.succession: Adopted son and heir of Hadrian

nodes.name: Lucius Verus
nodes.succession: Adopted son and heir of Antoninus Pius and son-in-law of Marcus Aurelius; Co-emperor with Marcus Aurelius until his death

nodes.name: Marcus Aurelius
nodes.succession: Adopted son, son-in-law and heir of Antoninus Pius; Co-emperor with Lucius Verus until 169. Last of the “Five Good Emperors”

nodes.name: Commodus
nodes.succession: Natural son of Marcus Aurelius; joint emperor from 177

nodes.name: Pertinax
nodes.succession: Proclaimed emperor by Praetorian Guard

nodes.name: Didius Julianus
nodes.succession: Won auction held by the Praetorian Guard for the position of emperor

nodes.name: Septimius Severus
nodes.succession: Seized power with support of Pannonian legions[a]

nodes.name: Caracalla
nodes.succession: Son of Septimius Severus; co-emperor with Severus from 198; with Severus and Geta from 209 until February 211; co-emperor with Geta until December 211

nodes.name: Geta
nodes.succession: Son of Septimius Severus; co-emperor with Severus and Caracalla from 209 until February 211; co-emperor with Caracalla until December 211

nodes.name: Macrinus
nodes.succession: Praetorian Prefect to Caracalla, probably conspired to have Caracalla murdered and proclaimed himself emperor after Caracalla's death; made his son Diadumenian (born on 14 September 208) co-emperor in May 218

nodes.name: Elagabalus
nodes.succession: Grandnephew of Septimius Severus, first cousin once removed and alleged illegitimate son of Caracalla; proclaimed emperor by Syrian legions

nodes.name: Severus Alexander
nodes.succession: Grandnephew of Septimius Severus, cousin and adoptive heir of Elagabalus

nodes.name: Maximinus Thrax
nodes.succession: Proclaimed emperor by Germanic legions after the murder of Severus Alexander

nodes.name: Gordian I
nodes.succession: Proclaimed emperor, whilst Pro-consul in Africa, during a revolt against Maximinus. Ruled jointly with his son Gordian II, and in opposition to Maximinus. Technically a usurper, but retrospectively legitimised by the accession of Gordian III

nodes.name: Gordian II
nodes.succession: Proclaimed emperor, alongside father Gordian I, in opposition to Maximinus by act of the Senate.

nodes.name: Pupienus
nodes.succession: Proclaimed joint emperor with Balbinus by the Senate in opposition to Maximinus; later co-emperor with Balbinus.

nodes.name: Balbinus
nodes.succession: Proclaimed joint emperor with Pupienus by the Senate after death of Gordian I and II, in opposition to Maximinus; later co-emperor with Pupienus and Gordian III

nodes.name: Gordian III
nodes.succession: Proclaimed emperor by supporters of Gordian I and II, then by the Senate; joint emperor with Pupienus and Balbinus until July 238; grandson and nephew of Gordian I and II, respectively

nodes.name: Philip the Arab
nodes.succession: Praetorian Prefect to Gordian III, took power after his death; made his son Philip II (born 237) co-emperor in summer 247

nodes.name: Decius
nodes.succession: Governor under Philip the Arab; proclaimed emperor by Danubian legions then defeating and killing Philip in the Battle of Verona; made his son Herennius Etruscus (born 227) co-emperor in early 251

nodes.name: Hostilian
nodes.succession: Son of Decius, accepted as heir by the Senate

nodes.name: Trebonianus Gallus
nodes.succession: Governor of Moesia Superior, proclaimed emperor by Danubian legions after Decius's death (and in opposition to Hostilian); made his son Volusianus co-emperor in late 251.

nodes.name: Aemilian
nodes.succession: Governor of Moesia Superior, proclaimed emperor by Danubian legions after defeating the Goths; accepted as emperor after death of Gallus

nodes.name: Valerian
nodes.succession: Governor of Noricum and Raetia, proclaimed emperor by Rhine legions after death of Gallus; accepted as emperor after death of Aemilian

nodes.name: Gallienus
nodes.succession: Son of Valerian, made co-emperor in 253; his son Saloninus (born c. 242) is very briefly co-emperor in c. July 260 before assassination by Postumus.

nodes.name: Claudius Gothicus
nodes.succession: Victorious general at Battle of Naissus, seized power after Gallienus's death

nodes.name: Quintillus
nodes.succession: Brother of Claudius II, seized power after his death

nodes.name: Aurelian
nodes.succession: Proclaimed emperor by Danubian legions after Claudius II's death, in opposition to Quintillus

nodes.name: Ulpia Severina
nodes.succession: Wife of Aurelian, there is evidence that she ruled in her own right during the interregnum between Aurelian's death and the election of Tacitus.[12][13]

nodes.name: Tacitus
nodes.succession: Elected by the Senate to replace Aurelian, after a short interregnum

nodes.name: Florianus
nodes.succession: Brother of Tacitus, elected by the army in the west to replace him

nodes.name: Probus
nodes.succession: Governor of the eastern provinces, proclaimed emperor by Danubian legions in opposition to Florian

nodes.name: Carus
nodes.succession: Praetorian Prefect to Probus; seized power either before or after Probus was murdered; made his son Carinus co-emperor in early 283

nodes.name: Carinus
nodes.succession: Son of Carus, ruled shortly with him (from early 283) as co-emperor and then in his own right with his brother Numerian

nodes.name: Numerian
nodes.succession: Son of Carus, succeeded him jointly with his brother Carinus

nodes.name: Diocletian
nodes.succession: Proclaimed emperor by army after death of Numerian, and in opposition to Carinus; adopted Maximian as senior co-emperor in 286

nodes.name: Maximian
nodes.succession: Adopted as senior co-emperor ('Augustus') in the west by Diocletian in 286

nodes.name: Galerius
nodes.succession: Adopted as junior co-emperor ('Caesar') and heir by Diocletian in 293. Also son-in-law of Diocletian.

nodes.name: Constantius Chlorus
nodes.succession: Adopted as junior co-emperor ('Caesar') and heir by Maximian in 293

nodes.name: Valerius Severus
nodes.succession: Adopted as junior co-emperor ('Caesar') and heir by Constantius Chlorus in 305; succeeded as Augustus in 306; opposed by Maxentius and Constantine I

nodes.name: Constantine the Great
nodes.succession: Son of Constantius I Chlorus, proclaimed emperor by his father's troops; accepted as Caesar (west) by Galerius in 306; promoted to Augustus (west) in 307 by Maximian after death of Severus II; refused relegation to Caesar in 309

nodes.name: Maxentius
nodes.succession: Son of Maximian, seized power in 306 after death of Constantius I Chlorus, in opposition to Severus and Constantine I; made Caesar (west) by Maximian in 307 after the death of Severus

nodes.name: Licinius
nodes.succession: Son-in-law of Constantius Chlorus, appointed Augustus in the west by Galerius in 308, in opposition to Maxentius; became Augustus in the east in 311 after the death of Galerius (shared with Maximinus II); defeated Maximinus II in civil war to become sole eastern Augustus in 313; appointed Valerius Valens in 317, and Martinian in 324 as western Augustus, in opposition to Constantine, both being executed within weeks.

nodes.name: Maximinus II
nodes.succession: Nephew of Galerius, adopted as Caesar and his heir in 305; succeeded as Augustus (shared with Licinius I) in 311

nodes.name: Constantine II
nodes.succession: Son of Constantine I; appointed Caesar in 317, succeeded as joint Augustus with his brothers Constantius II and Constans I

nodes.name: Constantius II
nodes.succession: Son of Constantine I; succeeded as joint Augustus with his brothers Constantine II and Constans I; sole emperor from 350

nodes.name: Constans I
nodes.succession: Son of Constantine I; succeeded as joint Augustus with his brothers Constantine II and Constantius II

nodes.name: Vetranio
nodes.succession: General of Constans, proclaimed Caesar against Magnentius and temporarily accepted as Augustus of the west by Constantius II.

nodes.name: Julian
nodes.succession: Cousin of Constantius II; made Caesar of the west in 355; proclaimed Augustus by his troops in 360; sole emperor after the death of Constantius

nodes.name: Jovian
nodes.succession: General of Julian's army; proclaimed emperor by the troops on Julian's death

nodes.name: Valentinian I
nodes.succession: Elected to replace Jovian by the army

nodes.name: Valens
nodes.succession: Brother of Valentinian I, appointed co-augustus (for the east) by him

nodes.name: Gratian
nodes.succession: Son of Valentinian I, appointed junior Augustus by him in 367, became senior Augustus (for the west) after Valentinian's death.

nodes.name: Valentinian II
nodes.succession: Son of Valentinian I, proclaimed emperor by Pannonian army after Valentinian's death; accepted as co-Augustus for the west by Gratian

nodes.name: Magnus Maximus
nodes.succession: Usurper in the West; legitimized along with his son Victor by Theodosius I as emperors of Britannia and Gaul.

nodes.name: Eugenius
nodes.succession: Usurper in the West; elevated to emperor by Arbogast.

nodes.name: Theodosius I
nodes.succession: Son-in-law of Valentinian I, appointed as Augustus for the east by Gratian after the death of Valens; became sole senior Augustus after death of Valentinian II (Eastern Emperor since 379)

nodes.name: Honorius
nodes.succession: Son of Theodosius I; appointed as junior Augustus for the west by Theodosius on January 23, 393 (after the death of Valentinian II); became senior Augustus for the west after his father's death

nodes.name: Constantine III
nodes.succession: Usurper who declared himself emperor in the west in 407, recognized as co-emperor by Honorius in 409. Elevated his son Constans II to co-emperor in 409, who was not recognized by Honorius. Neither recognized by the Eastern Empire.

nodes.name: Constantius III
nodes.succession: Married to Theodosius I's daughter Galla Placidia, elevated to co-Augustus for the west by Honorius; not recognized by the Eastern Empire

nodes.name: Joannes
nodes.succession: A senior civil servant under Honorius, proclaimed emperor by Castinus; not recognized by the Eastern Empire

nodes.name: Valentinian III
nodes.succession: Son of Constantius III, appointed Caesar for the west by Theodosius II after the death of Honorius, in opposition to the regime of Joannes; became Augustus for the west after the defeat of Joannes

nodes.name: Petronius Maximus
nodes.succession: Son-in-law of Theodosius II, proclaimed himself emperor with the support of the army, after the death of Valentinian III. Not recognized by the Eastern Empire. He appointed his son Palladius as caesar.

nodes.name: Avitus
nodes.succession: Magister militum under Petronius Maximus, proclaimed emperor by the Visigoth king Theoderic II after Petronius's death. Not recognized by the Eastern Empire.

nodes.name: Majorian
nodes.succession: Proclaimed emperor by his troops. Recognized by the Eastern Empire at the behest of Ricimer.

nodes.name: Libius Severus
nodes.succession: Appointed emperor by Ricimer. Not recognized by the Eastern Empire.

nodes.name: Anthemius
nodes.succession: Son-in-law of Marcian, appointed emperor by Leo I, with the consent of Ricimer.

nodes.name: Olybrius
nodes.succession: Son-in-law of Valentinian III; appointed emperor by Ricimer. Not recognized by the Eastern Empire.

nodes.name: Glycerius
nodes.succession: Appointed emperor by Gundobad (Ricimer's successor). Not recognized by the Eastern Empire.

nodes.name: Julius Nepos
nodes.succession: Nephew-in-law of the eastern emperor Leo I (and nephew of Marcellinus) appointed emperor in opposition to Glycerius

nodes.name: Romulus Augustulus
nodes.succession: Appointed by his father, Orestes. Listed as an emperor by historical convention. His rule never extended beyond portions of the Italian peninsula. Not recognized by Eastern Emperor Zeno.

nodes.name: Arcadius
nodes.succession: Son of Theodosius I; appointed as junior Augustus for the east by Theodosius in January 383; became senior Augustus for the east after his father's death

nodes.name: Theodosius II
nodes.succession: Son of Arcadius; appointed as junior Augustus for the east by Arcadius in 402; became senior Augustus for the east after his father's death

nodes.name: Pulcheria
nodes.succession: Daughter of Arcadius and sister of Theodosius II; reigned as co-empress with the younger Theodosius II through his reign from 414 onwards, sole ruler of the empire upon his death as Augusta and Imperatrix

nodes.name: Marcian
nodes.succession: Nominated as successor (and husband) by Pulcheria, ruled alongside her 450-453 and later alone

nodes.name: Leo I the Thracian
nodes.succession: Chosen by the army

nodes.name: Leo II
nodes.succession: Grandson of Leo I

nodes.name: Zeno
nodes.succession: Named co-emperor by his son Leo II on 9 February 474.

nodes.name: Basiliscus
nodes.succession: Seized throne from Zeno, Basiliscus appointed his son Marcus co-emperor at some point in 475.

nodes.name: Anastasius I Dicorus
nodes.succession: Son-in-law of Leo I

nodes.name: Justin I
nodes.succession: Elected by army

nodes.name: Justinian I
nodes.succession: Nephew of Justin I

nodes.name: Theodora
nodes.succession: Wife of Justinian I, in some sources described as his co-regent. Theodora had her own court and imperial seal,[14] participated in state councils and Justinian described her as "partner in my deliberations".[15]

nodes.name: Justin II
nodes.succession: Nephew of Justinian I

nodes.name: Tiberius II Constantine
nodes.succession: Adopted son of Justin II, regent from 574

nodes.name: Maurice
nodes.succession: Son-in-law of Tiberius II, appointed his son Theodosius (born in August 4 583/585) co-emperor in 590

nodes.name: Phocas
nodes.succession: Seized throne

nodes.name: Heraclius
nodes.succession: Revolt

nodes.name: Constantine III
nodes.succession: Son of Heraclius

nodes.name: Heraklonas
nodes.succession: Son of Heraclius; his brothers Tiberius and Martinus briefly served as co-emperors.

nodes.name: Constans II
nodes.succession: Son of Constantine III. succeeded his uncle Heraklonas after he was deposed as emperor.

nodes.name: Constantine IV
nodes.succession: Oldest son of Constans II, co-emperor since 654. His brothers Heraclius and Tiberius, co-emperors since 659, served as co-emperors until they were mutilated and deposed by Constantine in 681.

nodes.name: Justinian II
nodes.succession: Son of Constantine IV, co-emperor since 681

nodes.name: Leontios
nodes.succession: Revolt

nodes.name: Tiberios III Apsimaros
nodes.succession: Revolt

nodes.name: Philippikos Bardanes
nodes.succession: Revolt

nodes.name: Anastasios II
nodes.succession: Bureaucrat and secretary under Philippikos, he was raised to the purple by the soldiers

nodes.name: Theodosius III
nodes.succession: Chosen by troops

nodes.name: Leo III the Isaurian
nodes.succession: Rebellion

nodes.name: Constantine V
nodes.succession: Son of Leo III

nodes.name: Artabasdos
nodes.succession: Son-in-law of Leo III. Usurped throne. Proclaimed his son Nikephoros as co-emperor in 741/742

nodes.name: Leo IV the Khazar
nodes.succession: Son of Constantine V

nodes.name: Constantine VI
nodes.succession: Son of Leo IV

nodes.name: Irene of Athens
nodes.succession: Regent during minority of Constantine VI. Seized throne from son in 797. First Byzantine empress regnant.

nodes.name: Nikephoros I
nodes.succession: Rebellion

nodes.name: Staurakios
nodes.succession: Son of Nikephoros I

nodes.name: Michael I Rangabe
nodes.succession: Son-in-law of Nikephoros I, appointed his son Theophylact (born c. 793) as co-emperor on 25 December 811

nodes.name: Leo V the Armenian
nodes.succession: Rebellion, appointed his son Symbatios as co-emperor under the name Constantine on Christmas 813

nodes.name: Michael II
nodes.succession: Chosen after murder of predecessor

nodes.name: Theophilos
nodes.succession: Only son of Michael II and co-emperor since 821

nodes.name: Michael III
nodes.succession: Son of Theophilos

nodes.name: Basil I the Macedonian
nodes.succession: Previous co-emperor, full emperor upon death of predecessor.

nodes.name: Leo VI the Wise
nodes.succession: Son of Basil I (potentially in reality the son of Michael III), co-emperor since 870.

nodes.name: Alexander
nodes.succession: Son of Basil I, co-emperor since 879.

nodes.name: Constantine VII
nodes.succession: Son of Leo VI, co-emperor since 908.

nodes.name: Romanos I Lekapenos
nodes.succession: Regent for the young Constantine VII, crowned himself senior emperor during Constantine VII's minority. Proclaimed his three sons Christopher, Stephen and Constantine as co-emperors. Was overthrown by Stephen in 944, who briefly ruled as senior emperor (for a few weeks) until he himself was overthrown by Constantine VII.

nodes.name: Romanos II
nodes.succession: Son of Constantine VII

nodes.name: Nikephoros II Phokas
nodes.succession: Chosen by the army, acted as senior emperor during the regency of young emperors Basil II and Constantine VIII

nodes.name: John I Tzimiskes
nodes.succession: Nephew of Nikephoros II Phokas, succeeded as senior emperor and regent for the young emperors Basil II and Constantine VIII

nodes.name: Basil II
nodes.succession: Eldest son of Romanos II

nodes.name: Constantine VIII
nodes.succession: Second son of Romanos II, co-emperor since 962.

nodes.name: Zoe Porphyrogenita
nodes.succession: Daughter of Constantine VIII, succeeded on her father's death along with her sister Theodora. Her three husbands, Romanos III (1028–1034), Michael IV (1034–1041) and Constantine IX (1042–1050) ruled alongside her.

nodes.name: Romanos III Argyros
nodes.succession: Chosen by Constantine VIII to marry his daughter Zoe and succeed him as emperor.

nodes.name: Michael IV the Paphlagonian
nodes.succession: Succeeded Romanos III as Zoe's husband and emperor.

nodes.name: Michael V Kalaphates
nodes.succession: Nephew and adopted son of Michael IV.

nodes.name: Theodora Porphyrogenita
nodes.succession: Younger sister of Zoe, raised to co-empress in 1042.

nodes.name: Constantine IX Monomachos
nodes.succession: Zoe's third husband

nodes.name: Michael VI Bringas
nodes.succession: Chosen as successor by Empress Theodora

nodes.name: Isaac I Komnenos
nodes.succession: Rebellion

nodes.name: Constantine X Doukas
nodes.succession: Chosen successor of Isaac I Komnenos

nodes.name: Michael VII Doukas
nodes.succession: Son of Constantine X Doukas and co-emperor since 1059, resigned the throne in 1078. Reigned alongside his brothers Andronikos and Konstantios as co-emperors. Andronikos died in the 1070s while Konstantios briefly succeeded Michael as senior emperor before being handed over to the usurper Nikephoros III and exiled. Michael's son Constantine was also raised to co-emperor in 1074.

nodes.name: Romanos IV Diogenes
nodes.succession: Married to Constantine X's widow and senior emperor as guardian of her sons by Constantine X

nodes.name: Nikephoros III Botaneiates
nodes.succession: Rebellion

nodes.name: Alexios I Komnenos
nodes.succession: Rebellion, nephew of Isaac I Komnenos, appointed Constantine Doukas (a previous co-emperor under Michael VII) as co-emperor in 1081. Replaced Constantine with his own son John II in 1087.

nodes.name: John II Komnenos
nodes.succession: Son of Alexios I, co-emperor since 1087, appointed his son Alexios co-emperor in 1122

nodes.name: Manuel I Komnenos
nodes.succession: Son of John II

nodes.name: Alexios II Komnenos
nodes.succession: Son of Manuel I

nodes.name: Andronikos I Komnenos
nodes.succession: Nephew of John II (son of his brother Isaac), uncle of Alexios II, appointed his son John as co-emperor in November 1183

nodes.name: Isaac II Angelos
nodes.succession: Rebellion

nodes.name: Alexios III Angelos
nodes.succession: Rebellion, elder brother of Isaac II

nodes.name: Alexios IV Angelos
nodes.succession: Raised to the throne by the Fourth Crusade alongside his father Isaac II

nodes.name: Alexios V Doukas
nodes.succession: Coup in the Imperial Palace, son-in-law of Alexios III

nodes.name: Theodore I Laskaris
nodes.succession: His brother Constantine Laskaris was elected emperor by the citizens of Constantinople on the day the city fell to the Crusaders; he later fled to Nicaea, where Theodore organized the Greek resistance to the Latins. Proclaimed emperor after Constantine's death in 1205, Theodore was crowned only in 1208.

nodes.name: John III Doukas Vatatzes
nodes.succession: Son-in-law of Theodore I

nodes.name: Theodore II Laskaris
nodes.succession: Son of John III

nodes.name: John IV Laskaris
nodes.succession: Son of Theodore II

nodes.name: Michael VIII Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Senior emperor and regent of John IV Laskaris, grandnephew of John III by marriage and great-grandson of Alexios III

nodes.name: Andronikos II Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Son of Michael VIII

nodes.name: Michael IX Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Son of Andronikos II, reigned alongside him as co-emperor with full imperial style

nodes.name: Andronikos III Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Son of Michael IX, named co-emperor in 1316 and rival emperor since 1321. Deposed his grandfather Andronikos II in 1328 and reigned as sole emperor

nodes.name: John V Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Son of Andronikos III

nodes.name: John VI Kantakouzenos
nodes.succession: Maternal relative of the Palaiologi, declared co-emperor by John V in 1341 and recognized as senior emperor in 1347 following a civil war. Appointed his son Matthew as co-emperor in 1353

nodes.name: Andronikos IV Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Son of John V, co-emperor since 1352, deposed his father John V in 1376

nodes.name: John V Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Son of Andronikos III

nodes.name: John VII Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Rebellion, son and co-emperor of Andronikos IV, deposed his grandfather John V

nodes.name: Manuel II Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Son of John V, co-emperor since 1373. John VII Palaiologos, who previously usurped the throne in 1390, was proclaimed co-emperor in 1403, keeping the title until his death in 1408. John VII also proclaimed his son, Andronikos V, co-emperor but Andronikos died before his father, in 1407. The imperial status of John and Andronikos was purely honorary.

nodes.name: John VIII Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Son of Manuel II, co-emperor since 1416

nodes.name: Constantine XI Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Son of Manuel II

nodes.name: Thomas Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Son of Manuel II. Despot of the Morea since 1428 and ruled there until 1460 when he escaped to Italy as an exile.

nodes.name: Andreas Palaiologos
nodes.succession: Son of Thomas. Succeeded him as claimant to the titles of Roman Emperor and Despot of the Morea. Sold his claim to the imperial title to Charles VIII of France in 1494 and to the Catholic Monarchs in 1502, ending the direct line of claimants.
